results.title: The People mover
results.brief_description: A promotional film on a new type of twin hull ferry designed and built by a Hobart firm. It was built initially to transport people across the Derwent but is also available for overseas sales.

results.title: The Penguins of Macquarie Island
results.brief_description: Observes the habits of the various species of penguins which live on Macquarie Island. The film was compiled from record material photographed by members of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition and officers of the CSIRO. The penguins are seen marching to and from their rookeries, assembling on the beach, looking after their young, and at play. Various features, which distinguish one species from another, are illustrated.

results.title: The Penetrating eye
results.creator_credit: Eli Lilly and Company and Wexler Film Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the functioning of a scanning electron microscope and shows how an electron beam, instead of light waves, is used to produce revealing images of microscopically sized specimens. Scanning electron microscope photographs of biological specimens are show and interpreted as to the new information and technique.

results.title: Pencils
results.brief_description: Scenes showing children and adults writing, drawing, and doodling with every imaginable kind of pencil are intercut with sequences filmed at a factory where pencils are manufactured. The variety of pencils, sizes, shapes, colours and uses are conveyed without narration but with a lively musical score.

results.title: The Pencil
results.brief_description: A portrait of the pencil, showing the different types, its manufacture, use and abuse. A fascinating treatment of the subject, beautifully photographed, with musical ‘commentary’. Original electronic music by Georgi L. M. Nachoff and Karol Rattray.

results.title: The Peasant's pea patch: a Russian folk tale
results.creator_credit: Nick Bosustow, Stephen Bosustow Productions and Xerox Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Desire to read”.
This tall tale from Russian folklore follows the hilarious misadventures of a Russian peasant who tries in vain to protect his pea patch from a flock of hungry cranes. The film ends with the defeated peasant illustrating that, although life can be difficult, humanity somehow manages not only to survive but to survive in good spirit.

results.title: Pearson Island
results.brief_description: Pearson Island, in the Great Australian Bight, supports a varied native fauna. Sea-lions live there permanently, and the sea birds include penguins, terns, oyster-catchers and Cape Barron geese. Saltbush and she-oak forest on higher ground have land birds and a native rat and wallaby extinct elsewhere. Commentary by Roger Cardwell.

results.title: Pearls in the north [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Don Murray and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Examines the pearling industry in the far north of Australia. After a post-war decline the industry now has a bright future. Nine luggers, from Broome, with Japanese and Malay crews, work the rich pearlshell beds. Shows diving techniques and a cultured pearl farm.

results.title: Pattern for chemicals
results.creator_credit: Denis Segaller and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: An introduction to the use of refinery gases, as derived from the ‘cracking’ proccesses, as raw material for a new chemical industry. From the cracked gas molecules and others, the chemist and the chemical engineer have learned to fashion and construct in new ways the molecules of a great many useful substances.
